utterances: How was your trip?
My trip was great.
We were in Venice and it's the most remarkable city.
The food was wonderful and the people were very nice.
And we were there, we got a little bit of what they called the aqua alta, which is the high water.
So…
Right.
Well, Roger Wilkins, as best anyone can determine, did Martin Luther King go into that day expecting to use that famous refrain, I have a dream?
I think he did.
You know, Martin, like all great orators, builds - every speech is not something brand new.
They build on their own thought as it's come along and they build on lines that they have used and that have worked.
And Martin had made some speech which was very similar to this.
I believe it was in Detroit a few days before.
Now, that doesn't diminish the greatness of the speech.
I mean, anybody who thinks he just walked up there and said all this brilliant stuff never having thought of it is wrong.
Taylor Branch, does your research show that there was a bit of improvisation in that moment?
Certainly so, and I would disagree only slightly with Roger.
He was a preacher in the same sense that a jazz musician went back to things that worked.
But because this was such a momentous occasion, he had for once written out a whole new speech.
And he had that, and it's available to see all of its various revisions.
And the final text, he got through about half of it, and in fact you can see exactly where it broke off.
He couldn't bring himself to deliver this line: And so today let us go back to our communities as members of the International Association for the Advancement of Creative Dissatisfaction.
And this was kind of pompous and he wouldn't do it, and instead he launched off into a series of riffs.
Not just I have a dream, but let freedom ring, and with this faith, and a series - the best known of which of course is I have a dream.
Creative dissatisfaction just doesn't have quite the same ring as a refrain...
No.
The International Association for the Advancement of Creative Dissatisfaction.
And a number of people said that Mahalia said tell them about the dream, Martin.
This is Mahalia Jackson, the singer?
Mahalia Jackson, who had just sung.
And she was standing behind Dr. King along with lots of other people.
A number of people, enough for it to be credible to me as a historical matter, say that Mahalia Jackson kept urging Dr. King to tell them about the dream.
She was basically saying, play the hits, Martin.
This is a big crowd.
That's right.
And Mahalia told you to do something, you did it.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That's right.
Did everybody go away from that moment understanding that something really historic had happened?
Oh yeah, I think so.
It was such a joyous day; there was such a broad array of support from whites, Jews, Christians, labor.
For those of us who were born in segregation, as I was, to come and see this array of powerful white Americans coming in on our side was thrilling, uplifting.
And we went away, many of us, I among them, euphoric.
And I remember we were yelling freedom now, freedom now, everybody, yeah, freedom now, baby.
Got to have it.
Euphoric.
Roger Wilkins has been an activist, an author, a history professor and a participant in the March on Washington in 1963.
Thanks for coming by.
My pleasure.
Taylor Branch is the author of three books on Martin Luther King, most recently ""At Canon's Edge."" Thank you.
Thank you.
Enjoyed being here.
(Soundbite of song, ""How I Got Over"")
(Singing) How I got over, how did I make it over?
You know my soul looked back and wondered how I made it over.
How I made it over...
Mahalia Jackson on NPR News.
As Iraq's political factions try to form a unity government, complicating matters is the oil-rich city of Kirkuk.
Ethnic Kurds there would like to make the city part of their autonomous region in the north of Iraq.
But an Arab-Iraqi nationalist party did surprisingly well among voters there, and that has cast some doubt on Kurdish claims of a majority in the city.
NPR's Quil Lawrence traveled to Kirkuk and sent this report.
The city of Kirkuk contains nearly all of Iraq's diverse groups: Arabs, Turkomans and Kurds, Shiites, Sunnis and Christians.
With about a fifth of Iraq's oil wealth, the city could be a cornerstone of the new Iraq.
But since Iraq was created in the 1920s, Kirkuk has more often been where the country's structure crumbles.
We are sitting on a time bomb.
Putting it off any longer, it's just going to make matters worse.
Tanya Gilly is a Kurdish member of the outgoing parliament from Kirkuk.
The time bomb she's referring to is the dispute over the city, which has been unresolved throughout Iraq's history.
The Kurds say Saddam Hussein's ethnic cleansing changed the majority in the Province of Kirkuk from Kurd to Arab.
Since 2003, however, Kurds have returned.
Or if you ask the Arabs and Turkomans in the city, more Kurds than ever lived here have flooded in.
Arshad Rashad(ph) is a Turkoman who ran with the nationalist Iraqiya slate in Kirkuk.
(Foreign language spoken)
After 2003, half a million Kurds came back to Kirkuk and now they outnumber us, Rashad says, repeating a common allegation.
But even as he makes the claim, Rashad is smiling.
Despite the supposed half million Kurdish arrivals, the Arabs and Turkomans with Iraqiya won half the seats in Kirkuk.
Kurds won the other half.
Rashad himself was the second-highest vote getter in the province.
Either the Kurdish influx never numbered as high as Rashad claims or Kurdish turnout was very low.
(Soundbite of a rooster)
It's easy to find the Kurdish returnees to the city who live mostly in several slums, like this parking lot where 12 families have constructed shanties and a chicken coop.
…it came up to our knees a couple of times.
But…
Wow.
I was just listening to a briefing this morning by all sorts of county officials and fire officials.
It's just amazing to me they are still ordering mandatory evacuations.
You just think it's the third day.
We're on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday.
You just think there can't be any place left to evacuate.
The fires are spreading, as you said.
There's one that's of great concern on the northern regions of the county that has jumped the 5 minutes heading toward the San Onofre nuclear power plant.
The parts that they are most concerned about, I think, are the town of Julian, which sits on a mountaintop in the east county.
They are defending that, making a stand there.
And also on another mountain to the north, Palomar Mountain, which is home to the historic Palomar Observatory.
So firefighters are making a stand at both of those mountaintops.
And Carrie, the president arrives here tomorrow.
We just heard from Homeland Security Chief Michael Chertoff that federal resources are being brought into San Diego.
What are people saying here that they need the most?
Firefighters.
They need air support.
That's really what people want.
The large water-dumping aircraft and the fire retardant-dumping aircraft.

That is exactly what they have in these Federal emergency and disaster declarations; one that's pending is just what is needed right now, because that allows for states to bring in more resources to nearby states, and they need the air support.
And you could see - we see blue skies, so there is in certain areas of the county better visibility.
And so they can get more of those aircraft up in the air.
They just need a lot of it.
Yeah.
And you are sort of a veteran of covering these kinds of disasters.
A couple of years ago, you were in Houston at the Astrodome where thousands of Katrina evacuees where taken after the storm.
We're here at the Qualcomm Stadium, where there are about 10,000 evacuees.
And how do you compare the two?
I've been thinking about that a lot.
You just don't want to get into comparing misery stories.
There's just...
Yeah.
You just cannot compare misery.
But you know, we do have the football stadium and thousands of people here; you can see a lot of people in the parking lot have pup tents here and sleeping in their cars and doing whatever they can.
It feels eerily reminiscent of those times.
But it is a different disaster.
This is a larger county and there was so much misery there at the Astrodome.
People just were - had spent two or three days in New Orleans before they were evacuated.
There was a lot more trauma.
But I was just in Qualcomm Stadium and you hear these stories of people that have been sleeping.
This is their third night now.
You can't sleep in these shelters.
It's very difficult to get any rest and people are getting very weary.
And you came across some nursing home patients.
